profileText: A Representative from Massachusetts; born in Boston, Mass., March 5, 1798; attended the Boston Latin School; was graduated from Harvard University in 1817 and from the divinity school in 1820; member of the State house of representatives 1834-1837; mayor of Boston 1837-1839; served in the State senate in 1843-1844; elected as a Whig to the Thirty-first Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Robert C. Winthrop and served from August 22, 1850, to March 3, 1851; declined to be a candidate for renomination in 1850; treasurer of Harvard University 1842-1853; died in Cambridge, Mass., January 29, 1862; interment in Mount Auburn Cemetery.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by resignation of Robert C. Winthrop, and took his seat August 22, 1850.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Dexter, Franklin. A letter to the Hon. Samuel A. Eliot, Representative in Congress from the city of Boston, in reply to his apology for voting for the fugitive slave bill. By Hancock [pseud.] Boston: W. Crosby & H. P. Nichols, 1851.
Eliot, Samuel Atkins. Address before the Boston Academy of Music, on the opening of the Odeon, Aug. 5, 1835. Boston: Printed by Perkins, Marvin, & Co., 1835.
------. A letter to the president of Harvard College. By a member of the corporation. Boston: C.C. Little and J. Brown, 1849.
------. A sketch of the history of Harvard College. And of its present state. Boston: C. C. Little and J. Brown, 1848.

researchRecord.name: 1817-1861, approximately 2 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Samuel Atkins Eliot contain personal correspondence, 1817-1861; personal financial records, 1825-1858; articles and addresses, ca. 1824-1861, concerning mainly politics; scrapbook with clippings; and typescript of biographical sketch of Samuel Eliot by Mary E. Guild.

researchRecord.name: In the Charles William Eliot Papers, 1804-1945, 40 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Subjects include Samuel A. Eliot. A finding aid is available in the repository and online.

researchRecord.name: In the George Bancroft Papers, 1816-1890, 55 boxes, 54 volumes, and 1 oversize container.
In the Boston Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge Papers II, 1830-1843, 1 folder.
